response: What allowed you to feel proud in that moment?

What would shift if you offered yourself even a fraction of the care you offer others?
Can you name what’s underneath the pressure to get things right?
Where in your life does control feel helpful, and where does it feel limiting?
What might that uncomfortable emotion be trying to tell you?
Can you try to believe one kind thing someone has said about you?
What would it be like to let someone support you without fear of judgment?
What would your future self thank you for starting today?
What part of your story is waiting to be heard?
What are you avoiding feeling when you focus on control?
When did you first learn that being perfect made you feel more acceptable?

Who are you becoming as you move through recovery?
What do you want someone close to you to understand, but haven’t said out loud?
What does your current relationship with your body protect you from facing?
When things feel overwhelming, what actually helps you feel safer in your body or mind?
How do your control strategies affect the way you connect with others?
What would it feel like to respond to your shame with curiosity instead of criticism?
What are you beginning to understand about yourself that you weren’t ready to see before?
What part of you wants to change, and what part isn’t ready yet?
What feelings have you pushed aside lately, and what do they need from you?
What happens when something doesn’t go exactly as planned?
Who are you outside of how you look or what you weigh?
What kind of support would actually feel helpful to you right now?
What’s one thing you could do today that’s kind and grounding, even for five minutes?
What would your future self thank you for starting today?
What’s one thing you wish someone knew about your experience, without having to explain it?
What does holding on so tightly help you avoid?
What do you imagine could happen if you tried something different, even once?
What do you hope someone would say to you if they really understood what you’re going through?
What emotion do you keep hidden because it feels unacceptable to show?
What part of yourself feels most alive when you're not focused on food or appearance?
What would be different if your best effort was always enough?
What keeps you from reaching out, even when you know you need support?
How has your view of your body shaped how you let people in or keep them out?
What’s one thing you’ve done before that helped you feel just a little more steady?
What makes it hard to give up something that’s hurting you?
What’s something you miss that recovery could make possible again?
What’s something you’ve never said out loud — even to yourself?
What parts of you feel clearer or stronger when you imagine life after recovery?
What would it sound like to speak to yourself the way you speak to someone you deeply care about?
What are you afraid might happen if you stopped managing things so tightly?
Who helps you feel safe enough to be real — even if just a little?
What does shame tell you about asking for support, and is that story true?
What does the part of you that wants change say — and what does the part that’s scared say back?
If your body never changed, what would you still want your life to be about?
What’s a way you've learned to numb or push through pain that no longer works for you?
What’s something you haven’t done in a while that used to bring you peace or joy?
What’s something you feel but often talk yourself out of saying?
What does control protect you from feeling — and what does it keep you from experiencing?
What are three things about you that have nothing to do with your appearance or performance?
What’s a truth you’re holding back from someone important to you?
What’s one thing you’d be able to do more freely if recovery felt more possible?
What happens inside when you make a mistake?
What would change if you believed you were already doing enough?
What emotion are you hoping no one else sees?
What are you doing to stay okay right now — and is it still working?
What do you wish someone had said to you when you first began struggling?
What’s something your future self might be grateful you started today?
What part of yourself have you learned to hide because it felt 'too much'?
What would your life look like if you gave yourself permission to want more than just survival?
What have you been doing to get by that may no longer be serving you?
How has your need for control affected how close others can get to you?
What emotion do you feel under the surface but rarely name out loud?
Who do you hope to become once your life isn’t centered around managing your body or food?
What would become possible if 'good enough' could actually be enough?
What support have you longed for but never asked for?
What do you need most right now — even if it feels uncomfortable to admit it?
What’s the smallest possible step you feel open to trying?
What has your body been through — and what would it mean to honor that history?
What emotions might come up if you weren’t constantly planning, fixing, or managing?
What part of you is tired of fighting the same battles every day?
What’s something you’ve never shared because you feared it would change how people see you?
What do you want to be free to do, feel, or experience that you can’t right now?
What would it look like to care for yourself in a way that doesn’t cost you later?
What would it feel like to let someone see the parts of you you usually hide?
What makes it worth trying again, even after setbacks?
What’s something true about you that doesn’t depend on other people’s approval?
Where are you spending energy trying to be 'enough' — and who decides what that means?
What feelings do you try to stay ahead of, and what might happen if you let them catch up?
What’s something that brings you joy, even briefly, that has nothing to do with your eating disorder?
Who do you feel most guarded around — and what are you protecting?

What part of you might be trying to help, even if its way of helping is hurting you now?
When do you notice yourself pushing past what’s healthy, just to feel in control?
What’s a truth you carry that no one has ever said back to you?
What’s one thing you wish you could believe about your body, even if it feels far away?
What’s something in your life that recovery could make more possible or more meaningful?

What makes you you — even when everything else feels uncertain?
What are you managing so carefully that it might be covering something deeper?
What would it feel like to let someone see what you’re really struggling with?
What are you most afraid people would think if you didn’t get it right?
What part of life do you want to participate in more fully — even if it feels hard to admit?
What have you needed lately that you haven’t said out loud?
If things stayed the same for the next year, what would you be missing out on?
What’s something kind you could do for yourself that wouldn’t feel like giving up control?
What’s something you wish someone had believed about your experience?
What makes it hard to let go — and what might be waiting on the other side?
